terms.definition: Product Requirements Document - an internal document that outlines what a product should accomplish for users without defining specific implementation details
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides self-service support to users
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing teams to collaborate and maintain different versions
A lightweight markup language that uses plain text formatting syntax to create structured documents that can be converted to HTML
Search Engine Optimization - the practice of optimizing content to improve its visibility and ranking in search engine results
Search Engine Results Pages - the pages displayed by search engines in response to a user's query
Enhanced search results that display additional information like ratings, images, or structured data beyond the standard title and description
User Interface - the visual elements and interactive components through which users interact with a software application or website
Unique Selling Points - distinctive features or benefits that differentiate a product from its competitors in the market
Customer Experience - the overall perception and interaction a customer has with a company throughout their entire journey
Tone of Voice - the consistent personality and style used in written communication that reflects a brand's character and values
Keep It Simple, Stupid - a design principle that emphasizes simplicity and avoiding unnecessary complexity in products or documentation
A readability test that scores text based on sentence length and syllable count to determine the education level needed to understand the content
The process of adapting content for different languages, cultures, and regions to make it relevant for local audiences
Brief summaries of web page content that appear in search engine results to help users understand what the page contains
